sen.j: 七夕（しちせき、たなばた）は、日本、中国、台湾、ベトナム、朝鮮などにおける節供、節日の一つ。
sen.e: Tanabata (shichiseki) is one of the day of sekku/sechinichi (the day of the turn of season) in Japan, China, Taiwan, Vietnam and Korea.
Tanabata (shichiseki) is one of the days of sekku/sechinichi (a day of the turn of the season) in Japan, China, Taiwan, Vietnam, and Korea.
Tanabata (Shichiseki) is one of the days of sekku/sechinichi (a day of the turn of the season) in Japan, China, Taiwan, Vietnam, and Korea.

sen.j: 7月7日 (旧暦)の夜のことであるが、日本では明治改暦以降、お盆が7月か8月に分かれるように7月7日又は月遅れの8月7日に分かれて七夕祭りが行われる。
sen.e: Though it refers to the night of July 7 (lunar calendar), Tanabata is celebrated in Japan either on July 7 or a month later on August 7 after the lunar calendar was adopted in Meiji era, like the case of Bon festival which is also held either in July or in August.

Though it refers to the night of July 7 (lunar calendar), Tanabata is celebrated in Japan on July 7 or a month later on August 7 after the lunar calendar was adopted in Meiji era, like the case of Bon festival which is also held either in July or in August.

Though it refers to the night of July 7 (lunar calendar), Tanabata Matsuri is held in Japan either on July 7 or a month later on August 7 as Bon festival is also held either in July or in August, after the Meiji revision of the calendar.
sen.cmt: Tanabata→Tanabata Matsuri,celebrated→held,either を挿入しました。明治改暦： the Meiji revision of the calendar として修正しました。

sen.j: 節句の一つにも数えられる。
sen.e: It is also counted among sekku (seasonal festivals).

sen.j: 古くは、「七夕」を「棚機（たなばた）」や棚幡と表記した。
sen.e: In old days, tanabata (七夕) was written "棚機" or "棚幡".

sen.j: そもそも七夕とはお盆行事の一環でもあり、精霊棚とその幡を安置するのが7日の夕方であった。
sen.e: Originally, tanabata was a part of Bon festival and shoryodana (精霊棚) (a shelf for spirits of the dead) and bata (幡) (a kind of flag used for Buddhist events) used to be prepared on the evening of the 7th.

sen.j: 7日の夕で「七夕」と書いて「たなばた」と発音するようになったともいう。
sen.e: It is said that because the evening of the 7th is written in Chinese character as "七夕", people started to pronounce this Chinese character as "tanabata".

sen.j: 元来、中国での行事であったものが奈良時代に伝わった。
sen.e: Tanabata was originally an event celebrated in China and was introduced into Japan in the Nara period.

sen.e: The term tanabata was born when the above was combined with Japanese indigenous legend of Tanabatatsume.

sen.e: Originally it was one of sekku in China and was celebrated on July 7 based on a lunar-solar calendar (old calendar).

sen.j: 中国暦において7月 (旧暦)は秋の最初の月「孟秋」であり、7日は上弦の月すなわち半月の日である。
sen.e: Based on Chinese calendar, July (old calendar) is the first month of autumn called "moshu" (beginning of autumn) and the 7th is the day of waxing moon, namely the day of a half moon.

sen.j: 7が重なる日であるため「双七」とも呼ばれた。
sen.e: As the July 7 is written in Chinese character as 七月七日, it was also called "soshichi" (double seven).

sen.j: 二十四節気では立秋前後の時期に相当する。
sen.e: According to Nijushi-sekki (24 seasons), the day of tanabata falls around the time of risshu (the first day of autumn).

sen.j: 日本では天保暦（旧暦）など和暦7月7日であり7月15日 (旧暦)に行われるお盆に合わせてお盆行事の一環として行う意味合いが強かった。
sen.e: In Japan, the day of tanabata was July 7 of Japanese calendar such as Tenpo calendar (old calendar) and was celebrated mostly as a part of Bon festival, which was held on July 15 (old calendar).

sen.j: 明治6年（1873年）の改暦後は、お盆時期が7月と8月に分かれたが、七夕もグレゴリオ暦（新暦）の7月7日（行事によっては7月6日の夜）に勤める地域と、旧暦風（月遅れ）お盆の8月7日（東日本・北海道と仙台に多い）に行われるものとに分かれた。
sen.e: As the time of Bon festival split, depending on regions, into July and August after the solar calendar was adopted in 1873, tanabata is currently celebrated either on July 7 of Gregorian calendar (new calendar) (the night of July 6 depending on events) or on August 7 as a part of Bon festival based on the old calendar (a month late) (mainly, eastern Japan, Hokkaido and Sendai).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理

sen.j: また、現在でも旧暦の7月7日に行う地方もある。
sen.e: Even at present, tanabata is celebrated on July 7 of the old calendar in some regions.

sen.j: なお、旧暦の場合、閏月の関係で閏7月になることもあるが、閏月に年中行事は行わないため、閏7月7日は旧七夕とはならない。
sen.e: Although there exists a leap month in case of the old calendar, July 7 of leap month is not the day of old calendar-based tanabata because no annual events are held in a leap month traditionally.

sen.j: 最近では2006年がそうだった（7月31日が旧7月7日、8月30日が旧閏7月7日、旧七夕はあくまで新暦7月31日だけであり、年に2回あるわけではない）。
sen.e: In recent years, such a case occurred in 2006 (July 31 coincided with July 7 of the old calendar and August 30 coincided with July 7 of leap month. In this case, the day of old calendar-based tanabata is only July 31and tanabata is not celebrated twice a year).

sen.j: グレゴリオ暦の7月7日は夏だが、旧暦の7月7日はほとんど立秋以降であるので、古来の七夕は秋の季語である。
sen.e: Though July 7 of the Gregorian calendar falls in summer, July 7 of the old calendar mostly falls after the time of risshu and therefore, old calendar-based Tanabata is a season word of autumn.

sen.j: 日本の多くの地域では、グレゴリオ暦の7月7日は梅雨の最中なので雨の日が多く、旧暦のころからあった行事をグレゴリオ暦の同じ日付で行うことによる弊害の一つといわれる。
sen.e: As July 7 of the Gregorian calendar falls in the midst of the rainy season in most regions of Japan, it is pointed out that this is one of disadvantages to hold the traditional events according to the Gregorian calendar.

sen.j: 統計的には、旧暦で晴れる確率は約53%（東京）であり、晴れる確率が特別に高いというわけではない。
sen.e: According to statistics, the ratio of fine weather on July 7 of the old calendar is about 53% (Tokyo) and it is not particularly high.

sen.e: However, as July 7 of the old calendar is the day of waxing moon, the moon sets below the horizon early and the moonlight rarely hinder people in watching the Milky Way.

sen.e: Further, as the age of the moon on the day is irregular, the Milky Way could be invisible even on a fine day due to the effect of moonlight.

sen.e: Therefore, as far as the odds of being able to see the Milky Way is concerned, they are higher on July 7 of the old calendar.

sen.j: ちなみに、七夕に降る雨を「催涙雨（さいるいう）」また、「洒涙雨（さいるいう）」といい、織姫と彦星が流す涙だと伝えられている。
sen.e: Incidentally, a rain falls on the day of tanabata is called "催涙雨 (sairuiu)" or " 洒涙雨 (sairuiu)" and is believed to be tears which Orihime (Vega) and Hikoboshi (Altair) shed.

sen.j: 日本古来の豊作を祖霊に祈る祭(お盆)に、中国から伝来した女性が針仕事の上達を願う乞巧奠（きっこうでん/きこうでん）や佛教の盂蘭盆会（お盆）などが習合したものと考えられている。
sen.e: It is contemplated that tanabata was born when Japanese traditional festival in which people pray for a good harvest to the spirits of ancestors (Bon festival) was united with Kikkoden (Kikoden), a festival imported from China in which women pray for the progress of sewing, and the Buddhist festival of Urabon-e (Bon festival).

It is thoughtd that tanabata was born when the Japanese traditional festival in which people pray for a good harvest to the spirits of ancestors (Bon festival) merged with Kikkoden (Kikoden), a festival imported from China in which women pray for the progress of sewing, and the Buddhist festival of Urabon-e (Bon festival).

It is thought that tanabata originated as the Japanese traditional festival in which people pray for a good harvest to the spirits of ancestors (Bon festival) merged with Kikkoden (Kikoden), a festival imported from China in which women pray for the progress of sewing, and the Buddhist festival of Urabon-e (Bon festival).

sen.e: The oldest literature which mentioned the events held on this day was "Simin yueling" (book on agricultural work), a book written by Cui Shi in the Later term of Western Han period, and according to it, people aired out books on the day.

sen.j: その後、南北朝時代 (中国)の『荊楚歳時記』には7月7日、牽牛と織姫が会合する夜であると明記され、さらに夜に婦人たちが7本の針の穴に美しい彩りの糸を通し、捧げ物を庭に並べて針仕事の上達を祈ったと書かれている。
sen.e: In "Keiso Saijiki" written in the period of Northern and Southern Courts (China), it was stated that the Cowherd and the Weaver meet on July 7 and on that night, women prayed for the progress of sewing with piercing colorful threads into the eyes of seven needles and putting fried food at a garden.

sen.j: 日本語「たなばた」の語源は『古事記』でアメノワカヒコが死にアヂスキタカヒコネが来た折に詠まれた歌にある「淤登多那婆多」（弟棚機）又は『日本書紀』葦原中国平定の1書第1にある「乙登多奈婆多」また、お盆の精霊棚とその幡から棚幡という。
sen.e: The origin of Japanese "tanabata" is believed to be either "ototanabata (淤登多那婆多)" (ototanabata (弟棚機)), which appears in a poem, according to "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), written by Ajisukitakahikone when Amenowakahiko died, "ototanabata (乙登多奈婆多)", which appears in issho-daiichi of ASHIWARA no Nakatsukuniheitei of "Nihon shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) or "tanabata (棚幡), which derived from shoryodana (精霊棚) and bata (幡) used for Bon festival.

sen.e: In "Morisada Manko" written by Morisada KITAGAWA, there also is a description saying "The night of July 7 is tanabata. In Osaka, people play throughout the day while beating drums. In Edo, people hang colored tanzaku on a green bamboo and place it on a roof".

sen.e: Other than the above, there are descriptions in "Kiyu shoran" written by Kintei KITAMURA saying "from the 12th year of Bunsei in Edo" and in "Shojitome" saying "June of the 12th year of Tenpo is July in the normal years when tanabata is celebrated".

sen.j: さらに、斎藤月岑の『東都歳時記』には「七月六日、今朝未明より」、屋代弘賢の『古今要覧稿』には「たなばた祭、延喜式、七月七日織女祭と見えたるを初とせり」とある。
sen.e: Further, there are descriptions also in "Toto Saijiki" written by Gekkin SAITO saying "July 6, from the dawn of this morning" and in "Kokon Yoranko" written by Hirokata YASHIRO saying "tanabata firstly appeared in the Engishiki as shokujo-sai which is held on July 7".

tit.e: Tanabata based on the old calendar
Tanabata based on the old calendar
Tanabata based on the old calendar

sen.j: 国立天文台では2001年から、「新暦7月7日はたいてい梅雨のさなかでなかなか星も見られない」という理由で、旧暦7月7日を「伝統的七夕」と呼び、その日の新暦での日付を広く報じている。
sen.e: From 2001, the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan started to call July 7 of the old calendar "traditional tanabata" and announce the date of the new calendar that coincides with it on the ground that stars are often invisible since July 7 of the new calendar falls in the midst of rainy season.

From 2001, the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan started to call July 7 of the old calendar "traditional tanabata" and announced the date of the new calendar that coincides with it on the grounds that stars are often invisible since July 7 of the new calendar falls in the midst of the rainy season.

From 2001, the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan started to call July 7 of the old calendar as "traditional tanabata" and announced the date of the new calendar day that coincides with it on the grounds that stars are often invisible since July 7 of the new calendar falls in the midst of the rainy season.
sen.cmt: as を挿入しました。new calender→new calender day

sen.j: ただ、「旧暦」は現在は公には使われていないのに国の機関が「旧暦」で定義することはできない。
sen.e: Being a national institutes, however, the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan is not allowed to define the day of tanabata based on "the old calendar" since "the old calendar" is not used officially at present.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Being a national institute, however, the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan is not allowed to define the day of tanabata based on "the old calendar" since "the old calendar" is not officially used at present.

Being a national institute, however, the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan is not allowed to define the day of tanabata based on "the old calendar" since "the old calendar" is not officially used at present.

sen.j: このため、「伝統的七夕」の日は、旧暦7月7日に近い日として、「24節気の処暑（しょしょ＝黄道が150度になる瞬間）を含む日かそれよりも前で、処暑に最も近い朔（さく＝新月）の瞬間を含む日から数えて7日目」と定義している。
sen.e: Under such circumstances, it defines "the day of traditional tanabata" as the day which is the nearest to July 7 of the old calendar, namely "the seventh day after the day of new moon which falls on or before shosho (the moment when the ecliptic coordinates mark 150 degree) of 24 sekki (seasons) and is nearest to shosho.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理
sen.e: Under such circumstances, it defines "the day of traditional tanabata" as the day which is the nearest to July 7 of the old calendar, namely "the seventh day after the day of new moon which falls on or before shosho (the moment when the ecliptic coordinates mark 150 degree) of 24 sekki (seasons) and is nearest to shosho.

Under such circumstances, it defines "the day of traditional tanabata" as the day which is the nearest to July 7 of the old calendar, "the seventh day after the day of new moon which falls on or before shosho (the moment when the ecliptic coordinates mark 150 degree) of 24 sekki (seasons) and is nearest to shosho."
sen.cmt: namely を削除し、クォートの修正をしました。

sen.j: 天の川の輝きは淡いため、月明かりや光害の影響があると見ることが難しい。
sen.e: As the brightness of the Milky Way is faint, it is difficult to see it when disturbed by the moonlight or light pollution.

sen.e: As the brightness of the Milky Way is faint, it is difficult to see it when it's disturbed by moonlight or light pollution.

sen.j: 月齢は0が新月、7.5が上弦の月、14が満月、22.5が下弦の月である。
sen.e: A new moon refers to the moon when its age is 0, a waxing moon refers to the moon when its age is 7.5, a full moon refers to the moon when its age is 14 and a waning moon refers to the moon when its age is 22.5.
